title: Serene Firebug

description.text:
"Description is under moderation due to a Notice of Claimed Infringement" makes no sense.  Serene Firebug is not something that can be infringed, its first documented usage is here on thingiverse, by the author of this page.  Whatever, DMCA notice on shapes is a different thig... just wish Thingiverse would bother to let creators know when they had models censored from the site.  
I have no idea when this was taken down and only found out about this action when someone emailed me asking for a copy of the file.
If someone ever tries to DMCA you...  you DMCA them right back.

Doesn't Matter

No

Notes: To print vase's print with 0% infill, 0.00mm roof thickness and one perimeter.

Note: Wallet2 has more roundings and bugfixes, but I have not printed it yet.  
It is a very small wallet that hold your cards, money bills and coins together. A standard-sized card is used as a sliding lid, for example you can use your bank pass, library card, etc. This version also features a lid stopper. You can also put other cards inside by placing a long end in first, then drop the other side. Use the holes to push cards out again.   
I couldn't print the wallet this thing derived from, so I decided to make my own customizable version of it in OpenSCAD. Especially the height setting could be interesting, I have made a 12 mm version and a 17 mm version. I think the OpenSCAD file might still be buggy, so double check when you change something.  
An improvement could be to make the top more beveled, so it is more comfortable in your pocket.

• I printed it with my 0.5mm nozzle, 0.31mm layer height, 0.6mm layer width.

  • Choose your favorite card to slide in.

  • Put more stuff in :-)

This script can generate a box for lasercut.

Need Box ? Create your own box.
Define the size of the box and the thikness of the material that you use in your laser cutting machine.
The script generate the 6 faces of the box. Derivate as you wish. NB : This is not for 3D printers, it's for Laser cutting machine. Update 2015-12-18
Some people ask me for 3D print of the box.
So, just use the mount module without the translate() and rotate().
Build each piece as you wish.
But you have the limitations of your printer for the size of the box.
If you have a BIG 3D printer, let's play. 2015-12-14
new script. Correct orientation. Better code.
Change to match another project that use this code partialy.

The smoothstepper is an awesome motion control device for the equally awesome Mach3 CNC control software (I don't work for them, but have been using their stuff for a nearly a decade). Unfortunately, it comes as a raw board, so it needed a case.

This could be made on a reprap/makerbot, but I carved this one out of a piece of leftover exotic Purpleheart wood. Just mill it out and use #4-40 screws to mount the board inside. A lid is coming soon (honest)!

This is a Slide Whistle made from scratch using Autodesk Inventor. It was about a 6 week long project trying to make this, from sketching to all the way to making final assembly.

This is based off of a bass clarinet reed, but it is made of plastic. It consists of the mouthpiece itself, the reed, two screws, and a ligature. To assemble the parts, the flat side of the reed must line up on the flat side of the mouthpiece. To hold it down, the ligature goes over the mouthpiece, and the screws go through the threaded holes in the ligature. To make sound, one must blow into it as if he/she is playing a woodwind instrument.

title: Talk Like a Pirate Day Eyepatch

description.text: Arrrrr!!! Since this is a special day I decided to lazzzor something for the occasion.

I hot-airgunned it into a semi round shape for a better fit. You might also want to scale it before you lazzzor it. UPDATE: I uploaded a new version with more fearsome looking eyes an bigger mounting holes. Double up on all your adjectives and you'll be bountifully bombastic with your phrasing. Pirates never speak of "a big ship", they call it a "great, grand ship!" They never say never, they say "No nay ne'er!" Drop all your "g"'s when you speak and you'll get words like "rowin'", "sailin'" and "fightin'". Dropping all of your "v"'s will get you words like "ne'er", "e'er" and "o'er". Instead of saying "I am", sailors say, "I be". Instead of saying "You are", sailors say, "You be". Instead of saying, "They are", sailors say, "They be". Ne'er speak in anythin' but the present tense! pirate speech tips taken from: http://www.yarr.org.uk/talk/

author: prajnay88

description.text: Simple continuation of my pocket hanger idea, based off a bent copper prototype I've been using for around 9 months.

710mm Hexacopter (6 arms).
More info and pics at:http://blog.lowres.xyz/
Everything that can be 3d printed is 3d printed on the multi copter. (PLA).
710mm between motor centers
6x 800kv motors
2x 5000mha lipo batteries ~30minute flight time (23minute aggressive flying or 38 minutes chilled flying with Gopro camera).
Top speed ~85km/h.
Additional carry capacity about 2Kg.
6x Propellers 11x5
APM 2.6+ flight computer with GPS. The APM is cushioned on rubber vibration damping balls.
6x 16mm carbon fiber arms
Legs and additional struts are 9mm carbon fiber
Location pins are 4mm aluminum
All nuts and bolts are 3mm. Updated Hub (Copterhubv27_Updated.stl) which uses nuts/bolts instead of pins to locate the arms. Just pins were not a secure fit and vibration was wearing the Hub/Arms so there was play. The Nuts/Bolts prevent this and ensures a secure fit.

Printer:

Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20 - 30%

Notes: Parts should be printed for light weight and strength. 3 outer walls and ~25% infill, honeycomb.
My setup Motors, ESC's and batteries hardly get warm.
PLA is fine for parts which do not get hot, higher kv motors tend to get hotter so care needs to be taken.
More info and pics at:http://blog.lowres.xyz/
All parts drawn in Freecad All parts drawn in Freecad

author: Fitzroy

title: Skywalker FPV Pan and Tilt Turret

description.text: I never liked the plywood platforms that many Skywalker builds use to carry their FPV camera because I felt it ruined the Skywalkers nose. So I made this pan and tilt turret that sits inside the removable canopy. For pan I use a sail winch servo from HK which I limit on the transmitter so it only rotates 180 degrees each direction. The pitch servo is just a simple 9G hotglued to the back of the 600TVL Sony camera. The small cog is a friction fit on the servo head and you only need a bit of CA to glue down the hollow pin that holds down the turrets base. The outer dome is also just attached with a bit of CA. There is enough space for the cables of the camera and the 9G servo to be routed through the middle axis so the cables never get tangled or twisted. Here is a video of the whole thing in action: https://goo.gl/photos/iXJ8qKvhhXwxdMGB9

author: olarky

description.text:
An updated version of the spiral cup for those of you lucky enough to be able to print in stereo 3D! You could print it in red and blue and fill with silver (or white) starts for US based patriotic occasions. see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5014 for stars - scale at 50%. imprint your phone number or a stick a QRCode on the back of each star as a hand out, or fill with star shaped candies/mints. Or maybe print in Silver and Gold... Note for "would be" stereo STL generators:
I originally uploaded the base and top STL files after generating them using OpenSCAD. It quickly occurred to me that I hadn't thought about any overlapping regions between the two STLs. In the original combined STL, any overlapping objects in the scene would automatically become union-ed. But, in a two colour print, these areas would have both materials dispensed. I revised the base STL by subtracting (difference) the top STL from it prior to uploading. so, instead of:
pencilCup(true); in one STL and
pencilCup(false); in the other. I should have used:
pencilCup(true); in one STL and
difference() { pencilCup(false); pencilCup(true); } in the other.

As far as I can see, the experimental ToM MK7++++ dualtastic revision to RepG takes two (yes two!) STL files. These combine to become more than the sum of their parts... alternatively: Print them separately and spend hours trying to weave the two parts together, then glue all the broken bits and the joins together.

title: Hybrid Wade's-Bowden Dual Extruder Mount for Printrbot

description.text: This model adds a bowden mount position in front of (-Y) the existing Wade's extruder. I'm using this in my Printrbot Plus Dual Extruder project to add a 1.75mm bowden driven extruder in front of my stock 3mm Wade's extruder. You'll still need to add a bowden-to-hotend mount. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104005 The x-carraige was adapted from noreway's Printrbot Plus Quick-Fit Upgrade(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96230) Getting the two hotends absolutelty level (i.e. the nozzle at the same height,) is critical. I used washers to shim since this is still experimental. Eventually I will combine the Bowden/Ubis mount into this frame. The OpenSCAD code is not pretty, I need to return to it and clean it up for broader consumption.
I printed at a .8 infill to make this a very solid piece.  Don't skimp, this needs to be very rigid.

description.text: This is a 3D printable harmonica that can be printed out of plastic. It is based off of a real harmonica in the hope that it will be able to play like a real harmonica.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Yes
If assembly is required, assemble as depicted below. The top and bottom casings and the top and bottom reed plates are the same design, only they are rotated as shown. Exploded Assembly View

My class did this a project. We planned, designed, and presented our designs to the class. In my research, I discovered that all of the harmonica parts (even the reeds) can be made out of plastic. I based my harmonica on an actual harmonica, taking dimensions (with some changes to fit the constraints) in the hope that it will work.The presentation went well, and I would have been able to print it, but my design was too complicated. If it can be printed, I believe that it will work and be very loud. Casing Drawing Comb Drawing Reed Plate Drawing

author: eppapio

title: 966TT spoiler actuator guide 3D printed replacement part

description.text:
Update: Thanks to the collective Thingiverse knowledgebase, I've realized this part will become ridiculously malleable at reasonably low temps (170 F in my test). Parts just came out of the oven, and they are certainly very flexible. So, Porsche 966TT owner's out there should NOT install this.. :-) A friend emails me a schematic of a part for his Porsche 966TT spoiler actuator system. A guide buried in the assembly has failed. Apparently you can't buy that specific part, only the full assembly ($$$). Twelve hours later, the part is modeled, and 2 prototypes are printed. The next day, it goes in the mail. And the next day installed with a small amount of drilling to increase the diameter of a few holes by 0.015" (see images). Tinkercad.com project:
https://tinkercad.com/things/iOVOtPnGKyG Final installed/operational 966TT spoiler video:
http://youtu.be/l_ha02FtmGM Modeling system: Tinkercad.com
Printer: Replicator 2
Material: PLA

comments.text: Send the part file to Shapeways and have it printed in metal.
comments.author: Walt

comments.text: Great idea.  I didn't know they offered metal printing. I'll check it out.
comments.author: Walt

comments.text: PLA will be fine, as long as you never leave the car parked in the sun.  I'd suggest printing a spare in ABS.
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: PLA melting points 150-160 °C  302-320 °F
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: It won't melt, but it will get soft like silly putty, and easily deform under stress. I've had that happen in PA to PLA parts left in my car.
comments.author: MAKERFAM

comments.text: Good point.  Will have to check into that.  The location and function of this part might make this a problem.
comments.author: Landru

comments.text: Like jello at 60c.  If there's any stress on it, suspect it would start to deform around 45c.
comments.author: MAKERFAM

comments.text: Glass transition state is 50-60 C (122-140 F).
comments.author: SystemsGuy

comments.text: You all are absolutely correct.  Ouch!  Thanks for the advice guys.  I placed a few of my throwaway parts in the oven at 170 F and they came out absolutely flexible/floppy almost.  Not sticky, but I'm sure not far off from that.  I would agree, this independent auto parts manufacturer needs to make his first recall of a 3D printed part!  I've had both the Replicator 1 and 2, and printed perhaps a 1000 things, and this question has never come up.  I can't say I've seen any mention of it before, but haven't really gone looking.  This is the power of the InterWebz!
comments.author: SystemsGuy

description.text:
Afraid of dropping your Apple TV remote and shattering the glass? 3D Printing to the rescue! You can 3D print this simple bumper for your remote and stop worrying about dropping it or it flying out of your hands when gaming. This features openings for the IR sensor and charging port. Also, add a lanyard to the corner for extra security.
https://youtu.be/v5Aab-y6FII This bumper is designed for Ninajflex (or other flexible) filament, so DO NOT try printing it in hard plastic like PLA or ABS. Because of the rubber, it's actually grippy and feels great in your hands, so no more slipping! Want to modify the design to make it your own? Download the archive and use it in your favorite CAD modeling program! Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360
http://a360.co/1TkYja6 Wanna get some Ninjaflex filament? Check out the Adafruit shop!
https://www.adafruit.com/search?q=Ninjaflex&b=1

In short, the bottom part is 80,70,60 that should work on every machine and the top part is 55-30 in 5Â° steps so you can then find what overhead angles you can "live with", what the "good" ones are and what angles are unprintable. EDIT:
I have now added also a test_overhang_flat.stl after imho valid comment that overhang on the round and flat surface is not same, so here's the one to test the flat overhang. One side (right) is 60, 55, 50, 45Â° (with 90Â° in between) and other side (left) is 40,35,30,25,20Â° (with 90Â° in between).

Print the object - without support
There is also stl with only "TOP" part that is problematic so with overhang below 60Â° if you do not want to print the whole object as you know machine will work ok with up to 60Â°.

comments.text: Objects that are round in the XY-plane allow for higher overhang angles because you're also wrapping filament around the already printed perimeter. I would not be amazed at all of you could print completely horizontal overhangs or even slightly negative angles, as long as you're fusing the newly extruded material with the material that's there. I would be positively happy to find out that this is possible, though! As discussed in the RepRap in space objects ( http://blog.reprap.org/2009/10/printing-in-space.htmlhttp://blog.reprap.org/2009/10... ) and this thread ( http://dev.forums.reprap.org/read.php?14,27036http://dev.forums.reprap.org/r... ).

title: mbed 3D printer PCB

description.text:
This PCB connects an mbed microcontroller board [1] to a Sparkfun Quadstepper Motor Driver Board [2].
I use it for my RepRap Prusa Mendel 3D printer but you can use it for any CNC machine. The firmware [3] for the mbed board is based on the Tonokip firmware and is compatible to ReplicatorG using the fived driver. There are jumpers for a 100k thermistor, a hot-end (via 3.3V mosfet) and a thumb-joystick. Update: new version (mbedquadstepperminimalNOatmega8u2.brd) has 2 mosfets and 2 thermistors and 3 min-endstops pins... but no support for atmega8u2 or thumb joystick anymore... [1] http://www.mbed.org
[2] http://www.sparkfun.com/products/10507
[3] https://github.com/renebohne/RepRap-Firmware-for-mbed-microcontroller

You can mill (or etch) this PCB using single-sided material. There is only one jumper wire (on the top layer).
Adjust the firmware to your printer and have fun printing :)

This is an automatic-watch winder for the Printrbot Simple Metal 1403 printer. Movement of the bed during printing is harnessed to drive a simple gear that rotates a watch in an attached holder, winding it in the process. Fast or slow, every inch moved generates power. Version 1 and 2, mounted on the Y-axis arm failed miserably and performed marginally, in that order. Version 3 (current) works perfectly, a 45-minute print yielded 11 hours of running for a CROSS MEN'S PALATINO AUTOMATIC WATCH (Model: CR8008-01) that had been left to run down completely earlier on. BOM:
6 x M36mm screws (2 for cap, 4 for holder)
2 x M38mm screws
1 x 20mm washer See pictures for assembly instruction, video for the winding in action.
All print without support except for Holder, Chassis Bottom and Gear Next up… plans to incorporate a worm drive, so the holder unit can be mounted perpendicularly. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RFp4w2CkooM UPDATE 5 Dec 2015: A 2-hour print fully wound the watch and it ran for the last 40 hours.

In 2011, my daughter and I built a rather large 4-family wooden birdhouse for the Lexington, KY Arboretum's Birdhouse Display and Benefit Auction. We didn't want to sell it, so we put up an Instructable ( http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-make-the-bird-house/ ) detailing how to build one yourself. Now, we've made it much easier... although this 1/2-scale structure houses just one family. Features? Sized for various small bird species, removable roof for cleaning, printed with 5-10% fill provides air gap thermal barrier, angled vent & floor drain slots, internal "ladder" to ease bird egress, darn cute design. ;-)

Simply print 2 fronts, a body, and a roof. Paint or print the parts in appropriate colors; painting external parts can improve weather resistance. Glue/weld the fronts on the body (which is also used for mounting). The roof is held in place by a couple of pieces of velcro stuck on the inside of the front plates.  
Printed in PLA on MakerGear M2 using 0.3mm extrusion, single side wall and two top/bottom walls, 5% fill on roof, 10% fill elsewhere. Print times: front 1 hour, body 4 hours, roof 2 hours -- total about 8 hours.

title: Lego brick no. 2580 Support 2 x 2 x 5 Lattice Pillar, Complete Assembly x4

description.text: Combination of 4 rare Lego part #2580 Support 2 x 2 x 5 Lattice Pillars. These pieces are crazy-hard to find, only ever available in extremely small quantities or at very low quality, and exorbitantly expensive to purchase, especially in the color red. This specific model was created to help prototype the Lego Desktop Saturn-V Apollo-11 Mobile Launcher designed by Valerie Roche (@whatsuptoday19) and currently gathering support on Lego Ideas. Head over to https://ideas.lego.com/projects/124515 to help make the design a reality!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes: For best results, enable support structures (scaffolding) for entire model. Experiment with disable stitching and combining options to ensure the bottom of the model is open for attaching other pieces. I wasn't able to get it to print the top holes, but perhaps you'll have better luck with figuring out the best settings. For my particular Lego model, the holes weren't important, but let me know if you figure out how to print the piece with them! Also, as with most 3D printed Lego pieces, the model may need to be scaled up by 1 or 2 percent to allow pieces to fit together properly (I found most success, on an Ultimaker 2 at least, with both a 2.8% horizontal and 1% vertical increase). Your results may vary depending on the model of printer and material used.

Creating the model was fairly simple. I started with a single 2580 model taken from the free LDraw library, then I adjusted the scale in Blender, corrected some of the model's normals, and duplicated it three times. I then selected all 4 structures and exported them all as one .stl file. From there, it was a simple matter of trial and error figuring out the optimal slicing settings in Cura. The model in the pictures was my first attempt at printing, and I'd say it went pretty well!

My cat likes to wander around in the garden. But now winter is coming it is to cold to keep my window open for the cat. So i used an arduino to open the window when the cat jumps on table indoor or on the windowsill outdoors. I stays open for a few seconds and then closes again.
check it out on https://www.youmagine.com/designs/automatic-window-for-cat

comments.text: Funny how this problem just keeps coming back. (hmmm, I think there's cat related song of a similar vein).
comments.author: ehud42

comments.text: Yes, I know this project. very funny! and probably very effective too. Thanks for the link! I have seen some other solutions too. Luckily my problem was a bit simpler. Until now only my own cat has found the way onto my windowsill and he never brings me any presents :( i had been thinking about a cat door but my landlord doesn't want me to install one. The way I did it now I only have minimal damage to the window frame. It will be quite easy to bring it back into the previous state if i ever decide to move out.

title: Tiny Toy Dump Truck for dual extruder

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays Now that makerbot has made a dual head option for the thing-o-matic one of the coolest toys should now be possible to print without stopping and restarting the build process to add support material. Marked WIP until someone successfully prints one.

Use a normal plastic for toy-truck11-needs-support.stl (exactly the same as the original, copied here for convenience). Use a dissoluble plastic for toy-truck11-support-dual-extruder.stl. Soak the finished model in the solvent of choice (ie water for http://store.makerbot.com/makerbot-pva.html) until the support material is gone. Then marvel at your new toy.

description.text: THis is a slightly different version of Lamp-Poly1. The only change was to fillet the corners of the pentagon so it had a more organic shape. The print took slightly more than 17 hours with a layer height of 0.200 mm. For this print I used dark blue PLA filament and the 2 photos show the lamp in daylight with the light off and in a dark closet with the light on. I think a lighter color filament is a better choice - see Lamp-Poly1 for an example. This table lamp is designed to work with a "puck" battery operated LED light source. The lamp sits on top of a standard 68mm/2.75" diameter LED puck light that is powered by 3 AAA batteries. I bought 3 of these lights at Lowes for $9.98 batteries included. Here is a link to the puck light: http://www.lowes.com/pd_406110-43768-NS511-R6-306_1z0y4gqZ1z10d2u__?productId=4177463&pl=1
